Project Name: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: Copy print of Consuelo Flowerton. Original likely photographed early to mid 1920s. Date the item was re-photographed is unknown.|~|Consuelo Flowerton was a Ziegfeld Follies showgirl, stage and screen actress, and nightclub performer. She made her film debut in the silent film Camille (Metro Pictures Corporation, 1921) before returning to Broadway stage shows. She appeared in two more films, one long and one short-form, in 1924 and 1928 (neither produced or distributed by Columbia Pictures). Flowerton continued to perform in stage shows throughout the 1930s and early 1940s. These dates also coincide with her appearances as a nightclub performer (she sang and played violin). While Flowerton may not have appeared in a Columbia Pictures film, her daughter, Nina Foch, did. Foch appeared in eighteen Columbia films between 1943 and 1949.
Title: Consuelo Flowerton, actress and singer, conversing with a man, copyprint, early 1920s
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Summary: Text from negative enclosure: Consuelo Flowerton (mother of Nina Foch)

Description.note: Consuelo Flowerton was a Ziegfeld Follies showgirl, stage and screen actress, and nightclub performer. She made her film debut in the silent film Camille (Metro Pictures Corporation, 1921) before returning to Broadway stage shows. She appeared in two more films, one long and one short-form, in 1924 and 1928 (neither produced or distributed by Columbia Pictures). Flowerton continued to perform in stage shows throughout the 1930s and early 1940s. These dates also coincide with her appearances as a nightclub performer (she sang and played violin). While Flowerton may not have appeared in a Columbia Pictures film, her daughter, Nina Foch, did. Foch appeared in eighteen Columbia films between 1943 and 1949.
Title: Consuelo Flowerton, actress and singer, 1930s

Project Name: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books
Author: Greene, Graham, $d 1904-1991
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Title: Press tag describing a scene from The End of the Affair, circa 1955
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Summary: Text from negative enclosure: Deborah Kerr|~|Press tag: Cor3-1 Suspicion. Bendrix (Van Johnson), employs a private detective agency headed by Savage (Charles Goldner), when he believes the woman he loves is unfaithful to him, in this scene from David E. Rose’s “The End of the Affair,” which co-stars Deborah Kerr, Van Johnson and John Mills. The new Coronado Production, for world-wide release by Columbia Pictures, is produced by David Lewis, and directed by Edward Dmytryk, with David E. Rose as Executive producer. Lenore Coffee wrote the screen adaptation of this unusual and powerful best-selling Graham Greene story.

Project Name: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books
Author: Greene, Graham, $d 1904-1991
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Title: Press tag describing a scene from The End of the Affair, circa 1955
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.|~|ark:/21198/zz002jf012 (related image)
Summary: Text from negative enclosure: Deborah Kerr|~|Press tag: Cor 3-14. Desperate. “I’ll never leave you, Henry,” sobs Sarah (Deborah Kerr) to her husband (Peter Cushing), although she knows now she can never be with the man she so desperately loves, in this emotional moment from David E. Rose’s “The End of the Affair,” which co-stars Miss Kerr, Van Johnson and John Mills, with Peter Cushing heading the top featured cast. Produced by David Lewis and directed by Edward Dmytryk, “The End of the Affair,” which Columbia Pictures is to release world-wide, is based on the best-selling novel by Graham Greene. The screenplay was written by Lenore Coffee. Still by Lawrence [sic] Ridley.

Project Name: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Title: Deborah Kerr and Van Johnson in The End of the Affair, 1955
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.|~|ark:/21198/zz002jdxzm (press tag image)
Summary: Text from related press tag: Cor3-12. Tormented. “Only the moment counts with you Sarah,” says Bendrix (Van Johnson) as he torments himself with doubts about the faithfulness of the woman he loves (Deborah Kerr), in this emotional moment from the powerful David E. Rose production of “The End of the Affair,” which co-stars Deborah Kerr, Van Johnson and John Mills. Produced by David Lewis and directed by Edward Dmytryk, “The End of the Affair,” which Columbia Pictures is to release world-wide, is based on the best-selling novel by Graham Greene. Summary: Text from negative enclosure: Deborah Kerr|~|Related press tag: Cor3-P2. His First British Role. A new study of Van Johnson, who makes his first appearance in a British picture as Bendrix, the embittered writer who is involved in a passionate love affair with a married woman, in David E. Rose’s “The End of the Affair,” in which he co-starred with Deborah Kerr and John Mills. The complex character is said to give the famous Hollywood star one of the finest parts of his career, and one that consolidates the deep sincerity he displayed in such hits as “A Guy Named Joe,” and “Battleground.” Produced by David Lewis and directed by Edward Dmytryk, “The End of the Affair,” is based on the best-selling novel by Graham Greene, and is distributed world-wide by Columbia Pictures. Still by Lawrence [sic] Ridley.|~|Handwritten on photo: COR3-P2A

Summary: Handwritten on photo: COR3-P1A|~|Related press tag: Cor3-P1. Serious Role. Hollywood’s Van Johnson has one of the outstanding roles of his career as Bendrix, tormented, embittered writer who becomes involved in a passionate love affair with a married woman, in David E. Rose’s “The End of the Affair,” which co-stars Deborah Kerr, Van Johnson and John Mills. The new role, a complete departure from Van’s previous successes, marks the first time he has appeared before the cameras in the British studio. Produced by David Lewis and directed by Edward Dmytryk, “The End of the Affair,” is based on Graham Greene’s world-famous and best-selling novel of the same name and is to be distributed world-wide by Columbia Pictures. Still by Lawrence [sic] Ridley.|~|Text from negative enclosure: Deborah Kerr

Summary: Handwritten on photo: COR3-11A|~|Text from negative enclosure: Deborah Kerr|~|Text from related press tag: Cor3-11 Passionate Moment. Sarah (Deborah Kerr) and Bendrix (Van Johnson) cling desperately to their few moments of happiness during their brief, but passionate, relationship in David E. Rose’s “The End of the Affair,” which co-stars Miss Kerr, Van Johnson and John Mills. The new Coronado Production, for world-wide release by Columbia Pictures, is produced by David Lewis and directed by Edward Dmytryk. Lenore Coffee wrote the screen adaptation of this unusual and powerful, best-selling, Graham Green story. Still by Lawrence [sic] Ridley.

Project Name: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Title: Deborah Kerr and Peter Cushing in The End of the Affair, 1955
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.|~|ark:/21198/zz002jdxwk (press tag image)
Summary: Text from negative enclosure: Deborah Kerr|~|Handwritten on photo: COR3-14A|~|Text from related press tag: Cor 3-14. Desperate. “I’ll never leave you, Henry,” sobs Sarah (Deborah Kerr) to her husband (Peter Cushing), although she knows now she can never be with the man she so desperately loves, in this emotional moment from David E. Rose’s “The End of the Affair,” which co-stars Deborah Kerr, Van Johnson and John Mills, with Peter Cushing heading the top featured cast. Produced by David Lewis and directed by Edward Dmytryk, “The End of the Affair,” which Columbia Pictures is to release world-wide, is based on the best-selling novel by Graham Greene. The screenplay was written by Lenore Coffee. Still by Lawrence [sic] Ridley.

Description.note: Elliott Clawson did not write any screenplays that were produced by Columbia Pictures, including "The 13th Man." The date of the image is based on the fact that the last of the films mentioned in the text was released in 1929.
Title: Elliott Clawson, screenwriter, circa 1930-1939
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.|~|ark:/21198/zz002jfvc9 (back of a photo of this image)
Summary: Text from the back of a print of this image: [Press tag:] Elliott Clawson, who began writing for the screen in 1913, has to his credit such screen successes as “The Kaiser, the Beast of Berlin”, “The Phantom of the Opera”, “West of Zanzibar”, “The Road to Mandalay”, “The Leatherneck”, “Skyscraper”, “Sal of Singapore”, “Body and Soul”, “Earthbound”, “Those Who Dance” and “The Little Shepherd of Kingdom Come”. Ince, Goldwyn, Fox, M. G. M., Pathe, are a few of the studios that have been clamoring for his work in recent years. He has written five originals for Bill Boyd and three for Lon Chaney. In collaboration with Howard Higgin, noted writer and director, Clawson is now developing a sea mystery story that will give Jack Holt his greatest starring role. The story is entitled “The 13th Man”.|~|Text from negative enclosure: Elliott Clawson.

Description.note: Charles Belden was a screenwriter, though none of his scripts or stories were ever produced by Columbia. However, according to the Los Angeles Times article, “Greta Garbo Decides to Remain with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for Another Picture,” [2 Oct. 1934: 15], Columbia purchased “All His Geese Are Swans,” written by Belden and Frederick Stephant. The film does not seem to have been made.
Title: Charles Belden, screenwriter, circa 1934
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Summary: Text from negative enclosure: Charles Belden.|~|Handwritten on negative: L-1.

Summary: Text from negative enclosure: Constantine [sic] Bakaleinikoff (music).|~|On back of a photo of this image: [Press tag:] Constantine [sic] Balkaleinikoff. “Background music” for many of the most important motion pictures produced in Hollywood is composed or arranged by Constantine [sic] Bakaleinikoff, who once directed the Imperial Orchestra in Moscow. He is now attached to the Columbia studios, and scored the currently successful “Cocktail Hour,” as well as the unreleased picture, “Lady for a Day.” Recently he was guest conductor of the Philharmonic Orchestra of Los Angeles, by courtesy of Columbia. . [Stamp:] Please credit Carl De Voy, portrait artist, Columbia Studios.
